explanation:
To determine whether lfs_fs_deorphan violates the MISRA guideline that pointer targets should be const-qualified whenever possible, the next analyzer needs the typedefs/structs and the function declarations used in this function so it can examine pointer parameter types and whether the callees mutate the objects passed. Brief reasons: 

- lfs_t: definition of the top-level filesystem object (lfs parameter). Required to see which members are mutable and whether lfs_t* could/should be const. 
- lfs_mdir_t: type of local variables pdir and dir. Needed to know the types of &dir/&pdir and their members (tail, pair, split) to judge if pointers could be const. 
- lfs_pair_t: type of tail/pair arrays passed to many helpers (pdir.tail, pair). Needed to see whether these arrays are passed as const-qualified pointers in prototypes. 
- lfs_gstate_t: type of lfs->gstate and lfs->gdelta. Required to see whether passing &lfs->gstate to functions could be const. 
- lfs_stag_t: return/argument tag type used by lfs_fs_parent and lfs_dir_get; needed to understand tag/value pointer usage in calls. 

Function prototypes (next items) are required because the MISRA check hinges on the const-qualification of pointer parameters and whether the callee mutates the pointed-to object: 

- lfs_gstate_hasorphans: called with &lfs->gstate; prototype shows if it accepts const lfs_gstate_t*. 
- lfs_pair_isnull: called with pdir.tail; prototype shows whether it should accept const lfs_pair_t. 
- lfs_dir_fetch: called as lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &dir, pdir.tail); prototype reveals constness of lfs_t*, lfs_mdir_t* and tail parameter. 
- lfs_fs_parent: called with (lfs, pdir.tail, &parent); prototype shows whether pdir.tail could be const and whether parent is output (non-const). 
- lfs_dir_get: called with (lfs, &parent, ..., tag, pair); prototype indicates whether pair should be const or is filled (i.e., non-const). 
- lfs_pair_fromle32: called on pair/tail; prototype shows whether it mutates its argument (thus whether callers must pass non-const). 
- lfs_pair_issync: called with (pair, pdir.tail); prototype needed to see constness of both parameters. 
- lfs_gstate_hasmovehere: called with &lfs->gstate and pdir.pair; needed to determine if its parameters could/should be const. 
- lfs_tag_id: used to extract id from a tag value; prototype/type helps judge whether passing lfs->gstate.tag could/should be const. 
- lfs_fs_prepmove: called with lfs and NULL; prototype indicates constness of lfs_t* parameter. 
- lfs_pair_tole32: counterpart to fromle32; prototype shows whether it mutates its argument. 
- lfs_dir_orphaningcommit: called with (lfs, &pdir, attrs); prototype shows whether it modifies pdir (i.e., whether &pdir must be non-const) and constness of other pointer params. 
- lfs_dir_getgstate: called with (lfs, &dir, &lfs->gdelta); prototype reveals whether &dir and &gdelta are modified (non-const) or could be const. 
- lfs_fs_preporphans: final call; prototype shows constness of lfs_t* parameter. 
- lfs_gstate_getorphans: used to compute argument for lfs_fs_preporphans; prototype shows if it accepts const gstate pointer.

Having these type definitions and function prototypes lets the analyzer (1) inspect every pointer parameter used in lfs_fs_deorphan to see whether it is declared const in the callee, (2) determine whether the callee actually mutates the pointed object (based on prototypes/semantics), and (3) decide whether the pointers in lfs_fs_deorphan itself could/should point to const-qualified types without breaking semantics. Without these symbols the const-qualification decisions cannot be reliably assessed.
